title: How to Make Dried Cherries

steps.headline: Wash the cherries well in cool water and remove the stems.
Pit the cherries.
steps.description: This is much easier with a cherry pitter, which leaves the cherries whole, or you can cut them in half with a paring knife, and remove the pits.

steps.headline: Pat the cherries dry with paper towel.
Once dried, place the cherries, cut side up on baking sheets.
steps.description: Make sure they are not touching.

steps.headline: For the oven, or dehydrator, preheat to 165 F degrees, for about 3 hours, or until the tops look leathery and wrinkled.
steps.description: Then reduce heat to 135, for about 16-24 hours.

steps.headline: You can tell the cherries are done, when they start to look similar to raisins.
steps.description: They should be hard, but still pliable, a little bit sticky, and when you squeeze them, no liquid should come out.

steps.headline: If you would like to dry your cherries in the sun, it's almost the same procedure.
Place the patted dry cherries on trays, and cover them with cheesecloth.
steps.description: Also, it is a good idea to put the trays on top of something, so they're not on the ground.

steps.headline: Leave them in the sun for 2-4 days.
steps.description: It really depends on the temperature and humidity, so check them often.

steps.headline: Once they are fully dried, place the cherries in a 160 degree oven for 30 minutes.
steps.description: This will kill any (unlikely) bacteria that may have formed.

tyn: A cherry pitter, or a sharp knife
An oven, dehydrator, or a few warm, sunny days.
text: Wash the cherries well in cool water and remove the stems.  Pit the cherries. This is much easier with a cherry pitter, which leaves the cherries whole, or you can cut them in half with a paring knife, and remove the pits. Pat the cherries dry with paper towel.  Once dried, place the cherries, cut side up on baking sheets. Make sure they are not touching. For the oven, or dehydrator, preheat to 165 F degrees, for about 3 hours, or until the tops look leathery and wrinkled. Then reduce heat to 135, for about 16-24 hours. You can tell the cherries are done, when they start to look similar to raisins. They should be hard, but still pliable, a little bit sticky, and when you squeeze them, no liquid should come out. If you would like to dry your cherries in the sun, it's almost the same procedure.  Place the patted dry cherries on trays, and cover them with cheesecloth. Also, it is a good idea to put the trays on top of something, so they're not on the ground. Leave them in the sun for 2-4 days. It really depends on the temperature and humidity, so check them often. Once they are fully dried, place the cherries in a 160 degree oven for 30 minutes. This will kill any (unlikely) bacteria that may have formed.

This is much easier with a cherry pitter, which leaves the cherries whole, or you can cut them in half with a paring knife, and remove the pits.
Pat the cherries dry with paper towel.

Make sure they are not touching.
For the oven, or dehydrator, preheat to 165 F degrees, for about 3 hours, or until the tops look leathery and wrinkled.
Then reduce heat to 135, for about 16-24 hours.
You can tell the cherries are done, when they start to look similar to raisins.
They should be hard, but still pliable, a little bit sticky, and when you squeeze them, no liquid should come out.
If you would like to dry your cherries in the sun, it's almost the same procedure.
Place the patted dry cherries on trays, and cover them with cheesecloth.
Also, it is a good idea to put the trays on top of something, so they're not on the ground.
Leave them in the sun for 2-4 days.
It really depends on the temperature and humidity, so check them often.
Once they are fully dried, place the cherries in a 160 degree oven for 30 minutes.
This will kill any (unlikely) bacteria that may have formed.
